sourceText: Born in 1736 in Manchester, the second of eight children, Ann Lee had no formal education. After several jobs, including a stint in a textile factory, at 22 Lee joined an English sect called the Wardley Society. Nicknamed the Shaking Quakers for their ecstatic dancing and singing during worship, the group later became known as The Shakers. A Protestant group, the Shakers believed the second coming of Christ would be in female form, and that Lee embodied this second coming. They also believed that men and women share the same responsibilities to each other and the world.

sourceText: In 1762, Lee married Abraham Standerin, a blacksmith. They had four children, all of whom died in infancy. Lee believed the people of Manchester were being corrupted by the Church of England, and at one point referred to the Church of England as damned.

Lee and other Shakers were also harassed and attacked by mobs for their beliefs.

targetText: A lawyer advising private equity sales told the BBC that after the Tiger Global ruling, deal valuations and calculations must be redone in case of tax scrutiny, increasing due diligence and paperwork. Investments made before 2017, previously considered tax-exempt, are now at high risk.

sourceText: Tax advisers say the ruling has shaken confidence. Amit Maheshwari, a tax partner at AKM Global, a consulting firm with a focus on cross-border transactions, says firms advised clients based on the law of the land at the time, but now see settled positions being reopened years later. He warns this reversal creates deep uncertainty.
targetText: Tax advisers say the ruling has shaken confidence. Amit Maheshwari of AKM Global notes that firms advised clients based on existing laws, but now previously settled positions are being reopened, creating significant uncertainty.

sourceText: During her trial, Lan had tried to hold on to her two Hermès bags, telling the court that she had bought one of them in Italy and the other was a gift from a Malaysian businessman. She said she wanted to leave the bags as keepsakes for her children and grandchildren.
targetText: During her trial, Lan tried to keep two Hermès bags, claiming she bought one in Italy and received the other as a gift, saying she wanted them as keepsakes for her children and grandchildren.

sourceText: U.S. President Donald Trump’s neo-colonial posturing at the World Economic Forum in Davos could mark the opening salvo of what may be termed great-power climate wars — an irony, given that it is being waged by a climate-change denier. As global warming is rapidly melting Arctic polar ice, it has sharpened interest in the Northern Sea Route (NSR), which promises to cut shipping time between East Asia, western Europe and North America. The route also carries geopolitical implications: it enables tighter trade and market integration between China and the Western Hemisphere — an outcome Mr. Trump has often sought to obstruct. At Davos, his renewed suggestion that the U.S. could “purchase” Greenland has rattled allies and revived colonial anxieties. The remark came even as Sara Olsvig, chair of the Inuit Circumpolar Council, has said that “there’s no such thing as a better coloniser”, reflecting on over three centuries of Danish rule.
targetText: At the Davos World Economic Forum, U.S. President Donald Trump’s suggestion that the U.S. could “purchase” Greenland sparked concern, highlighting tensions over Arctic resources. Melting polar ice has increased interest in the Northern Sea Route, which shortens shipping between East Asia, Europe, and North America and strengthens trade links between China and the West—an outcome Trump has often opposed. The comment revived colonial anxieties, with Inuit leaders criticizing it in the context of centuries of Danish rule.

sourceText: During its 33 years in the public domain, the internet has had several transformations, from the blog posts era to the social media era to the AI revolution. With each new iteration, information has become more unreliable, more bite-sized, more polarising. Amidst this, Wikipedia, which turned 25 this month, seems like a throwback to the early internet: Not offering the eye-catching features of ever-evolving technology, but stolidly building a database of knowledge. What began as a website distrusted by serious seekers of knowledge, who viewed it as being synonymous with sloppy, low-effort work, now offers, as per a Nature investigation, accuracy comparable to that of Encyclopaedia Britannica.
targetText: Over 33 years, the internet has evolved from blogs to social media to AI, often making information less reliable and more polarizing. In contrast, Wikipedia, now 25, steadily builds a knowledge database. Once dismissed as sloppy, it now matches Encyclopaedia Britannica in accuracy, according to Nature.

sourceText: The University Grants Commission’s new regulations against discrimination in higher education — the UGC (Promotion of Equity in Higher Education Institutions) Regulations, 2026 — are significant and welcome. They have sparked protests on the grounds of overreach and there are accusations that it ignores upper-caste concerns. Yet, the context that produces them shows why they are much needed. UGC data provided to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Education in 2025 shows that over the last five years, the number of reported complaints of caste-based discrimination on educational campuses has gone up exponentially — from 173 in 2019-20 to 378 in 2023-24. It makes the regulations, which replace those from 2012, both urgent and necessary. If the 2012 regulations officially recognised social discrimination, the new ones call out caste discrimination in classrooms by its name and move the needle by institutionalising mechanisms of redress.
targetText: The UGC’s new 2026 regulations against discrimination in higher education are significant and necessary. Complaints of caste-based discrimination on campuses have more than doubled in five years, rising from 173 in 2019–20 to 378 in 2023–24. Unlike the 2012 rules, the new regulations explicitly address caste discrimination in classrooms and establish mechanisms for redress.

sourceText: Certainly, the framework they put in place is not beyond critique. Despite Union Education Minister Dharmendra Pradhan’s assurance that misuse will “not be allowed against anybody”, there will be challenges. The inclusion of Other Backward Classes (OBC), while welcome, will need to be addressed with rigour. Concerns have also been raised about the possibility of false complaints of discrimination, and over the feasibility of timelines prescribed for inquiries, which may strain under-resourced institutions. The threat of punitive action for non-compliance, including derecognition, has stoked anxieties. For the regulations to succeed, checks and balances and safeguards against misuse, and a commitment to due process, will be critical.
targetText: While the UGC regulations are welcome, challenges remain. Issues include addressing OBC inclusion rigorously, preventing false complaints, managing tight inquiry timelines, and handling punitive actions for non-compliance. Success will require safeguards, checks and balances, and a commitment to due process.

sourceText: The comedian George Carlin used to characterise “military intelligence” as an oxymoron. One wonders what he would have made of monkey intelligence. A study published in the journal npj Complexity has found that spider monkeys in Mexico’s Yucatán peninsula run an elaborate intelligence-gathering operation. Agents are dispersed in cells, scout different areas, split and recombine seamlessly into different cells and brief each other, pooling and synthesising their knowledge to build up an increasingly granular intelligence picture.
targetText: A study in npj Complexity found that spider monkeys in Mexico’s Yucatán run a sophisticated intelligence-gathering system: they operate in cells, scout areas, split and merge seamlessly, and share information to create a detailed collective knowledge picture.

sourceText: In his first “Mann ki Baat” of the year, Prime Minister Narendra Modi mentioned the trend of bhajan clubbing. It is the name given to a new wave of spiritual expression, where bhajans are being reimagined in a contemporary, club-style format — in the PM’s words, it is about “spirituality and modernity merging beautifully”.
targetText: In his first “Mann ki Baat” of the year, PM Narendra Modi highlighted the trend of bhajan clubbing, where traditional bhajans are being reimagined in a modern, club-style format, blending spirituality with contemporary music.

sourceText: Every generation interprets culture in ways that it can recognise and respond to. Bhajan clubbing is a modern twist to the call-and-response format, engineered for maximum crowd participation, especially from the young and the restless. In a world measuring its life by the gloss of social media, one that is roiled by political turbulence, bhajan clubbing appears like a tether, a way to connect with oneself, an attempt to reach one’s roots.
targetText: Bhajan clubbing gives a modern twist to traditional call-and-response bhajans, designed to engage young audiences. In today’s social-media-driven and politically turbulent world, it offers a way to connect with oneself and one’s roots.

sourceText: An unsporting spectacle is playing in the cricket arena, involving bans and ultimatums and brinkmanship. That this is unfolding between two nations and two neighbours with overlapping histories and cultural intimacies that have contributed to regional stability makes it even more of a self-goal for India and Bangladesh. Sports is not always insulated from politics, and it is true that India-Bangladesh ties are currently in a fragile moment. Even so, the ICC diktat that has forced Bangladesh out of the upcoming T20 World Cup, and the events that led up to it, showcase the takeover of an escalatory reactiveness and a paralysis of long-termist diplomacy. This is more so in India, the much larger player, on and off the field.
targetText: A tense and unsporting situation is unfolding in cricket between India and Bangladesh, involving bans and ultimatums. While sports often intersect with politics, the ICC’s decision to exclude Bangladesh from the T20 World Cup highlights short-term escalation and a lack of long-term diplomacy, especially by India, the larger player.

sourceText: India’s sporting ambition gets stronger by the day. It will host the 2030 Commonwealth Games and is bidding for the 2036 Olympics, amid dreams of gold medals and proposals of world-class infrastructure projects. Grand sporting spectacles and freeze-frames of the nation’s young standing proud on podiums are healthy markers of national aspiration. But India’s big dreams are in danger of turning foggy because of the toxic air that hangs over its sporting hubs. At the India Open badminton tournament in New Delhi last week, a top international player pulled out because of the capital city’s exceptionally high levels of AQI. Some have flagged their concerns to the International Olympic Committee. The problem is far worse for Indian athletes who live and train in the country.
targetText: India’s sporting ambitions are growing, with plans to host the 2030 Commonwealth Games and bid for the 2036 Olympics. However, high pollution levels threaten these goals—at the India Open badminton tournament in New Delhi, a top international player withdrew due to poor air quality, a problem that is even more severe for domestic athletes.

sourceText: Sportspersons across disciplines speak about pollution and extreme heat eating into their training cycles and causing long-lasting health problems. More worryingly, the unhealthy outdoors also cut the play time of children in the local park, reducing their physical activity and increasing the risk of illness. India’s unclean air is also being flagged in other sectors and arenas. At the World Economic Forum, for instance, economist Gita Gopinath, who has served as the first deputy managing director of the IMF, said that pollution poses a bigger threat to India’s economic growth than tariffs.
targetText: Athletes report that pollution and extreme heat disrupt training and harm long-term health, while poor air quality limits children’s outdoor play, increasing illness risk. Economist Gita Gopinath has also warned that pollution threatens India’s economic growth more than tariffs.

sourceText: For over 11 months now, Manipur has been under President’s Rule. At the outset, few would have disputed the move, given the evident inability of former chief minister N Biren Singh — widely seen as a partisan figure — to contain the ethnic conflict. But almost 33 months since the violence first erupted, Manipur remains carved up into buffer zones that rigidly segregate the Meitei and Kuki-Zo communities.
targetText: Manipur has been under President’s Rule for over 11 months. While initially seen as necessary due to former CM N Biren Singh’s inability to manage ethnic conflict, 33 months after the violence began, the state remains divided into buffer zones separating the Meitei and Kuki-Zo communities.

sourceText: In 2022, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, even as the world was recovering from the post-pandemic supply chain disruptions, sent international prices of food and other commodities soaring. The benchmark FAO Food Price Index scaled an all-time high of 160.2 points in March and Brent crude futures crossed $139 per barrel on March 7 that year. In contrast, the recent geopolitical storms — whether in Venezuela, Iran or Greenland, not to speak of US President Donald Trump’s seeming upending of the world order — have had minimal effect on the global commodity trade. The FAO index is well below the 2022 peaks, averaging 124.3 points in December, while Brent prices are at around $65 per barrel now.
targetText: Russia’s 2022 invasion of Ukraine, amid post-pandemic recovery, drove food and commodity prices to record highs—FAO Food Price Index hit 160.2 in March, and Brent crude rose above $139 per barrel. In contrast, recent geopolitical events in Venezuela, Iran, Greenland, and global tensions, including actions by Trump, have had minimal impact, with the FAO index at 124.3 and Brent around $65 per barrel.

sourceText: It’s telling — and disquieting — that nearly 60 per cent of the orders passed in the last three years by the News Broadcasting & Digital Standards Authority (NBDSA) were against programmes that violated its ethics code on communal harmony. An analysis of the NBDSA orders since 2023 in this newspaper points to a brutish and cynical race to the bottom in a time of churn. Faced with intensifying competition in a far more crowded and fragmented media landscape than before, television channels and digital broadcasters have chosen the path of maximum shrillness and least resistance, becoming megaphones of the powerful — and the hateful. In the social media age, where no one needs a TV studio to broadcast to the world, they are trying to mimic its worst aspects. Because it rewards extremes, outrage and spectacle, channels and platforms are jostling each other to abandon responsibility and to frame news in ways that purvey divisive spectres and stereotypes.
targetText: Nearly 60% of NBDSA orders in the past three years targeted programs violating communal harmony rules, reflecting a media race to the bottom. Facing intense competition, TV and digital broadcasters amplify sensationalism, extremes, and divisive narratives, mimicking the worst aspects of traditional media in the social media age.

sourceText: There are high costs of this abdication. There is an unchecked sharpening of polarisation and shrinking spaces for deliberation and dialogue. In a plural and diverse democracy constitutionally committed to protecting the freedom of citizens to profess, practise and propagate their religion, this backsliding is worrying. But the price must be paid not just in terms of the fraying of the larger promise of democracy.
targetText: The consequences are serious: growing polarization, reduced spaces for dialogue, and a decline in democratic values, especially in a diverse society committed to religious freedom, signal troubling backsliding beyond just the erosion of democracy’s broader promise.

sourceText: A son marries, a family recalibrates, grievances accrue, rivening the parents and the newlyweds. Brooklyn Beckham’s estrangement from his parents after his marriage to heiress Nicola Peltz has the unmistakable familiarity of a Greek tragedy restaged for the algorithmic age: There is hubris, inheritance and the terrible knowledge that the ending was foretold long before anyone hit “post”. In a six-slide Instagram post, the 26-year-old Brooklyn closed the door on reconciliation, accusing parents David and Victoria of inauthenticity and control, and of having overshadowed his 2022 wedding.
targetText: After marrying heiress Nicola Peltz, Brooklyn Beckham became estranged from his parents, echoing a modern Greek tragedy. In a six-slide Instagram post, he accused David and Victoria Beckham of control, inauthenticity, and overshadowing his 2022 wedding, closing the door on reconciliation.

sourceText: When title inflation is rampant across so many industries, one should not begrudge the humble reader their wish for a promotion. This is a time of “voracious” readers (who presumably devour, rather than read, books) and Bookstagrammers. Dating apps have respectable populations of “sapiosexuals” revelling in their nerd cred. Books, for some, have become commodities, to be possessed, aesthetically displayed and perhaps, consumed in impressive quantities.
targetText: In an era of rampant title inflation, readers’ desire for recognition is understandable. Many avid readers and Bookstagrammers treat books as status symbols, showing off their collections and consuming them in impressive quantities, while dating apps attract “sapiosexuals” who take pride in their literary knowledge.

sourceText: Conceived in 1976 as an industrial township, an absence shapes the New Okhla Industrial Development Authority’s governance architecture: It is run by a state-appointed development authority and not by an elected municipal corporation, insulating it from public accountability.
targetText: Founded in 1976 as an industrial township, the New Okhla Industrial Development Authority is governed by a state-appointed development authority rather than an elected municipal corporation, leaving it largely unaccountable to the public.

sourceText: Nitin Nabin has formally taken charge as the BJP’s new national president a little over a month after he was named its working president, with the surprise of his previous anointment yet to fade. The elevation of the five-term MLA from Bihar is in keeping with the functioning of the BJP high command, which revels in overturning expectations. It also wraps its decisions in symbolism.
targetText: Nitin Nabin has officially become the BJP’s national president, just over a month after being named working president. His elevation, a surprise, reflects the BJP high command’s tendency to defy expectations and imbue its decisions with symbolism.

sourceText: India and Pakistan failed to resolve their differences over preparing a single comprehensive draft, with Pakistan sticking to its reservations on the question of military bases and acceptance of the principle of bilateralism in settlement of disputes. However, on the second day of the talks, Pakistan put forward a revised draft giving new formulations regarding these two issues.
targetText: India and Pakistan could not agree on a single comprehensive draft, as Pakistan maintained its reservations on military bases and bilateral dispute resolution. On the second day, Pakistan proposed a revised draft with new formulations on these issues.

sourceText: Weeds are a known threat to agricultural produce, growing at their expense by competing with them for nutrients, water and sunlight. Most of these unwanted plants are above the ground, making them amenable to manual removal. The problem is with weeds that attach to the roots of plants. By the time their shoots come out and are visible, the damage is done.
targetText: Weeds threaten crops by competing for nutrients, water, and sunlight. While most above-ground weeds can be removed manually, root-attaching weeds are problematic because they cause damage before their shoots become visible.

sourceText: The problem highlights the need for agricultural R&D as an imperative for the country’s food security. The urgency is even more in the context of climate change and the emergence of new pathogens and weeds. If weeds cannot be removed by hand, and with labour becoming scarce, more efforts are required at breeding varieties or hybrids that can “tolerate” the application of herbicides.
targetText: The issue underscores the need for agricultural R&D to ensure food security, especially amid climate change and new pests. With manual weeding becoming difficult due to labor shortages, efforts should focus on developing crop varieties or hybrids that can tolerate herbicide use.

sourceText: In ancient Rome, it was a faux pas not to water down one’s wine — only barbarians did that. Several explanations have been advanced for this, including that it wasn’t so much about diluting the wine as mitigating the foul taste of the contaminated water in ancient cities.
targetText: In ancient Rome, not watering down wine was considered uncivilized. This practice likely aimed not at diluting the wine itself but at masking the bad taste of contaminated city water.

sourceText: There are times when history repeats itself not as tragedy or farce, but as a troubling combination of both. Since last week, the political conversation in Punjab has been dominated by reports of attacks on businesses associated with the proprietors of the Punjab Kesari group, including notices for excise violations at a Jalandhar hotel, withholding of government advertisements, and police deployment at and around the presses where the newspaper is printed and dispatched from.
targetText: Since last week, Punjab’s political discourse has been dominated by attacks on businesses linked to the Punjab Kesari group, including excise notices at a Jalandhar hotel, withheld government ads, and heavy police presence at the newspaper’s printing and dispatch locations.

sourceText: Tune in to the U-19 World Cup, and regional South Asian dialects would be almost as audible as the English twang. There is a Hindi speaker in 10 of the 16 teams that participate in the tournament; there is at least one cricketer who understands Punjabi in seven teams; and one who can speak Gujarati, Telugu and Malayalam in four teams. There are Urdu, Tamil, Sinhala, and Marathi speakers in teams from outside the Subcontinent.
targetText: At the U-19 World Cup, South Asian languages are widely spoken alongside English. Hindi appears in 10 of 16 teams, Punjabi in seven, Gujarati, Telugu, and Malayalam in four, while teams from outside the Subcontinent include speakers of Urdu, Tamil, Sinhala, and Marathi.

sourceText: The pattern is a reflection of the shifting sands in world cricket. A game that was once segregated on racial lines in Africa, divided along social lines in England and Australia, that once saw a prominent British politician, Lord Tebbit, envisage a “loyalty test” for migrants, has become more inclusive and diverse. Two youngsters of Pakistani descent are the pillars of the England team; two Indians and two Sri Lankans are regulars in Australia’s side.
targetText: Cricket, once divided by race and class, has become more inclusive and diverse. The England team features two players of Pakistani descent, while Australia’s side regularly includes two Indians and two Sri Lankans.

sourceText: The BJP’s upper hand in the Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC) may mean the end of nearly three decades of Thackeray dominance in the city of the undivided Shiv Sena’s birth. Over the years, in vibrant, cosmopolitan Mumbai, where the Marathi manoos has long been outnumbered, the nativist pitch that formed the core of the Thackeray cousins’ campaign has found increasingly limited resonance.
targetText: The BJP’s lead in the Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation could end nearly 30 years of Thackeray dominance. In cosmopolitan Mumbai, where Marathi speakers are now a minority, the Thackerays’ nativist appeal has lost much of its influence.

sourceText: A handful of flattened rice, soaked in water for a few minutes (not more, else it loses its texture), a bowl of curd (mix water if it’s thick), and a spoonful of pickle. This is the standard recipe for dahi chooda, sometimes taken as comfort food, and on occasion, to mark a ceremony.
targetText: Dahi chooda is made with a few minutes of soaked flattened rice, curd (thinned if thick), and a spoonful of pickle. It is eaten as comfort food or during special ceremonies.

sourceText: A film was made and duly sent to the Central Board of Film Certification (CBFC), which asked the makers to implement some cuts before it could be certified for release. It should have been a straightforward process, from conception to release, pausing only at the mandated stop at the CBFC.
targetText: A film was submitted to the CBFC, which requested some cuts before certification, a process that should have been straightforward from creation to release.

sourceText: In a country of a thousand languages, whose people count in their heritage contributions of migrants and conquerors, poets and pirs, stories and histories that originate beyond its current borders, that is not an easy question. Take the bandhgala, which, to most people who aren’t enthusiasts of sartorial history, appears Indian by its very name.
targetText: In a linguistically diverse country shaped by migrants, conquerors, poets, and histories from beyond its borders, defining what is “Indian” is complex. For example, the bandhgala, though it sounds Indian, may not be.

sourceText: India and Germany may differ on several issues, not least in their respective approaches to Russia in the wake of its 2022 invasion of Ukraine. Yet amid the geopolitical disruptions unleashed by the American president nearly a year into his tenure, both New Delhi and Berlin recognise the need to find common ground.
targetText: Despite differences, including their approaches to Russia after its 2022 Ukraine invasion, India and Germany acknowledge the need to find common ground amid geopolitical disruptions under the U.S. president.

sourceText: But in at least one sense, pet dogs had it better than human kids. No dog mom or dad has ever compared their canine companion unfavourably to the neighbour’s pooch or complained about them being underachievers.
targetText: In one way, pet dogs are better off than human children, as owners never compare them negatively with others or label them as underachievers.

sourceText: A study published in Science last week has made global headlines. Researchers found that Gifted Word Learner dogs can “acquire novel words by overhearing third-party interactions” in much the same way that human toddlers do. Not only can these genius dogs label hundreds of items, they can also pick up vocabulary by eavesdropping on human conversations.
targetText: A recent study published in Science reports that Gifted Word Learner dogs can learn new words by overhearing human interactions, much like toddlers, and are able to understand and label hundreds of objects by picking up vocabulary from conversations.

sourceText: In the accusation of sexual misconduct levelled by a trainee shooter against her coach are the contours of a grimly familiar story, of an outsized power asymmetry being exploited to abuse and threaten a vulnerable young person in what should be safe spaces.
targetText: The allegation of sexual misconduct by a trainee shooter against her coach reflects a familiar pattern of power imbalance being misused to exploit, abuse, and intimidate a vulnerable young person in spaces meant to be safe.

sourceText: The swift response of the NRAI — which has also issued a show cause notice to Bhardwaj, and apprised its Internal Complaints Committee of the case — stands in stark contrast to how similar cases have often played out in the past. The half-hearted and delayed response to the allegations of sexual harassment raised in 2023 by India’s women wrestlers against Brij Bhushan Sharan Singh, the then president of the Wrestling Federation of India and MP, is just one example.
targetText: The NRAI’s prompt action, including issuing a show-cause notice and informing its Internal Complaints Committee, contrasts sharply with the delayed and inadequate handling of past cases, such as the 2023 sexual harassment allegations by India’s women wrestlers against then WFI chief Brij Bhushan Sharan Singh.

sourceText: A medical college in Katra that got the National Medical Commission’s green signal to run an MBBS course just four months ago is now asked to shut it down, four days after an inspection conducted in haste. The latest NMC decision unabashedly short-circuited due process — there was no show-cause notice to the college, no room for appeals.
targetText: A medical college in Katra that was approved by the National Medical Commission to offer an MBBS course only four months ago has now been ordered to shut it down after a hurried inspection conducted just four days earlier. The decision bypassed due process, with no show-cause notice issued and no opportunity for the college to appeal.

sourceText: Hungarian filmmaker Bela Tarr, who died this week at the age of 70, was a master of cinema as mesmerism. The glacial pace of his films, with an average shot of two and a half minutes, demand more than the audience’s attention; those used to films composed of two-and-half-second shots have to prepare for total surrender. For, Tarr was a man of both enormous talent and towering ambition, committed to putting life itself on the screen, with all its beauty, banality and tawdriness — an endeavour hardly conducive to the neat patterns that mainstream cinema has trained viewers to expect.
targetText: Hungarian filmmaker Bela Tarr, who died this week at 70, was known for his hypnotic cinema marked by extremely long shots and a slow pace that demanded complete audience immersion. His films rejected mainstream conventions, aiming instead to portray life in all its beauty, ordinariness, and rawness.

sourceText: The Indian economy is expected to grow at a healthy 7.4 per cent in 2025-26, as per the first advance estimates released by the National Statistics Office. Growth this year is considerably higher than what many analysts, including the RBI, had expected at the beginning of the year.
targetText: India’s economy is projected to grow by 7.4% in 2025–26, according to the National Statistics Office’s first advance estimates, exceeding the expectations of many analysts and the RBI at the start of the year.

sourceText: The disaggregated data shows that the sharpest acceleration is in the services sector. The sector is pegged to grow at 9.1 per cent in 2025-26, up from 7.2 per cent in 2024-25, with all segments — trade, hotels, transport and communication, financial, real estate and professional services and public administration — growing at a faster clip.
targetText: The data shows that the fastest growth is in the services sector, which is expected to expand by 9.1% in 2025–26, up from 7.2% in 2024–25, with all its segments growing more rapidly.

sourceText: The sources of Delhi’s air pollution are well-known. Studies have shown that vehicular exhaust, industrial emissions, and dust from construction sites combine with the fumes from seasonal farm fires to create the national capital’s chronic public health hazard.
targetText: Delhi’s air pollution is caused by a mix of vehicle emissions, industrial pollution, construction dust, and smoke from seasonal farm fires, creating a persistent public health crisis.

sourceText: The year has started on a negative note for exporters in India as the European Union has extended its Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) to imports into the EU. The CBAM is a tax on companies, based on the level of carbon emissions generated during production.
targetText: India’s exporters have begun the year facing a setback as the European Union has extended its Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism, a tax on imports based on the carbon emissions produced during manufacturing.

sourceText: In the 18th and 19th centuries, collectors descended on artefacts from around the globe and took them home. Ancient sculptures from the acropolis of Athens became the Elgin Marbles.
targetText: In the 18th and 19th centuries, collectors took artefacts from across the world to their home countries, including the Elgin Marbles from Athens.

sourceText: In 2023, it came to light that some 1,500 objects, including gold jewellery and semi-precious stones, had been stolen over the years, allegedly by the museum’s former curator for Greece and Rome, with many items sold off online. Reportedly, the museum has recovered more than a third of these thanks to its staffers, but now it’s seeking a dedicated hunter to track down the rest.
targetText: In 2023, it was revealed that about 1,500 artefacts were allegedly stolen by a former curator, many sold online; while over a third have been recovered, the museum is now seeking someone to trace the remaining items.

sourceText: The new year began on a jarring note for many women on X (formerly Twitter) whose photographs were manipulated into sexually explicit images using the AI chatbot Grok. In the days since, the flood of objectionable content — including of minors — has done little to ease concerns about the misuse of this technology.
targetText: AI-generated sexually explicit images created using the chatbot Grok, including those of minors, have sparked serious concerns at the start of the year, highlighting the growing misuse and dangers of such technology.

sourceText: Alarmed by the proliferation of non-consensual images, authorities worldwide have urged X to take action. These include the Government of India, which warned the company over its “serious failure” on enforcement of safeguards and about the violation of provisions of the IT Rules, 2021 and the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023.
targetText: Authorities across the world, including the Indian government, have urged X to act against the spread of non-consensual images, warning the platform of serious failures in enforcing safeguards and violations of India’s IT Rules, 2021 and the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023.

sourceText: Sometimes, it’s good if no one hears a tree fall in the forest and better still if the rotting log is left as is. In the Western Ghats in Kerala, under decaying wood, a unique concatenation of ecological circumstances provides the only known home for Melanobatrachus indicus or the Galaxy Frog. The tiny amphibian (0.8-1.4 inches long) is among the most stunning in the world and is named for the dazzling array of white spots on its jet black body. Unlike the frogs from fairy tales, it requires no assistance from princesses to be attractive, and it is this beauty, perhaps, that has led to a tragic fate.
targetText: The Galaxy Frog, found only under decaying wood in Kerala’s Western Ghats, is a tiny, striking amphibian whose unique habitat and beauty have made it both remarkable and vulnerable.

sourceText: According to a report published by researchers in Herpetology Notes, seven Galaxy Frogs — the species is vulnerable to extinction according to the IUCN — have disappeared in the last few years. The culprit is all but certain: Photographers rushed to the small patch of forest the frogs were known to live in. In their enthusiasm for the perfect image, tourists and amateurs overturned the logs under which they live and picked up the tiny creatures to place them against “better” backgrounds. In essence, they damaged the microhabitat that the tiny amphibian needs to survive.
targetText: A Herpetology Notes report states that seven Galaxy Frogs, a species listed as vulnerable by the IUCN, have vanished in recent years. The likely cause is photographers disturbing their microhabitat—upturning logs and moving the frogs for photos—damaging the delicate environment they rely on.

sourceText: As expected, the Indian cricket board’s decision to eject Bangladesh pacer Mustafizur Rahman from IPL 2026 has triggered a storm. In a quick counter to the snub, Bangladesh has refused to travel to India for next month’s World T20 and, in turn, India has expressed reluctance to cross the border for bilateral games later in the year. After the Pakistan logjam, the cricketing gate to Bangladesh, too, has been slammed shut.
targetText: The BCCI’s decision to exclude Bangladesh pacer Mustafizur Rahman from IPL 2026 has sparked tensions, with Bangladesh refusing to tour India for the World T20 and India hesitant to play bilateral matches, effectively closing the cricketing gate between the two nations.

sourceText: Cricket, or sports, shouldn’t be the rope in the tug of war between nations, especially those with longstanding ties. But these are times when the political takeover of sports seems complete. Directly or by proxy, politicians govern cricket in the Subcontinent. The days of apolitical administrators, the incurable cricket romantics, are in the past. There was a time in the Subcontinent when cricket held the power to soothe frayed nerves, open new vistas, give normalcy a chance. But the present-day political quagmires and volatile international relations have pushed the joy of the ordinary cricket-adoring masses down the priority list.
targetText: Cricket should unite nations, not become a tool in political conflicts, but in the Subcontinent, politics now dominates the sport. Once a source of joy and normalcy for fans, cricket’s ability to bring people together has been overshadowed by political interference and strained international relations.

sourceText: Few will shed a tear for Nicolas Maduro. His autocratic rule hollowed out Venezuela’s institutions, crushed dissent, subverted elections and violated human rights. The pre-dawn US operation to capture and transport him to New York on charges of drug trafficking may be presented as making Venezuela a safer place but how it was carried out suggests the opposite. Indeed, the manner in which US President Donald Trump has taken out a sitting president — through an air, land and sea assault that penetrated the capital — sends a message far beyond Caracas. It tells the world that the so-called rules-based order, already badly frayed, exists largely as a slogan. Be it Vladimir Putin in Ukraine, or Trump himself, first in global trade and now in Venezuela, anything goes. Doesn’t matter if it’s illegal, lacking Congressional authorisation at home or UN Security Council sanction abroad.
targetText: Nicolas Maduro’s authoritarian rule harmed Venezuela’s institutions and human rights, but the US pre-dawn operation to capture him in Caracas highlights a disregard for international rules. The operation signals that the global “rules-based order” is largely symbolic, showing that leaders like Trump or Putin can act without legal or international authorization.

sourceText: Telecom and aviation were amongst the most robust success stories in the post liberalisation era, transformed by the entry of several new private players. But today, both sectors are characterised by market concentration. The aviation sector in India is dominated by two players  — IndiGo and Air India. In the telecom sector, two strong private players —Jio and Airtel — account for around 75 per cent of the market. Vodafone Idea, which is a financially weak third player and partly owned by the government, occupies 16.5 per cent of the market, while state-owned BSNL accounts for just 8 per cent.
targetText: Telecom and aviation, once thriving from private competition after liberalization, are now highly concentrated. In aviation, IndiGo and Air India dominate, while in telecom, Jio and Airtel hold about 75% of the market, with Vodafone Idea and state-owned BSNL trailing far behind.

sourceText: As recent events in the aviation sector have also shown, this degree of market concentration has unhappy consequences. It underlines the need to facilitate healthy competition in sectors across the economy. In this context, reports pointing to the possible government exit from Vodafone Idea are welcome.
targetText: Recent aviation sector events show that high market concentration has negative effects, highlighting the need for healthy competition. In this light, reports of a potential government exit from Vodafone Idea are seen positively.

sourceText: Vodafone Idea has been in a precarious financial position. As of December 2024, its total debt was around Rs 2.3 lakh crore, comprising AGR dues and spectrum liability. Its subscriber base has fallen from 213 million in September 2024 to 203.5 million in September 2025. A few days ago, the Union cabinet approved a relief package for the beleaguered telco, freezing its AGR dues (adjusted gross revenue) and rescheduling their payment over a 10-year period ending in FY41. Alongside providing clarity over its dues, as per a report in this paper, the government is also exploring the option of bringing in an investor, who could eventually take majority control. A new investor could infuse money into the telco to ensure its long-term viability.
targetText: Vodafone Idea, burdened with about Rs 2.3 lakh crore in debt and a declining subscriber base, received a government relief package in December 2025 that freezes its AGR dues and spreads payments over 10 years. The government is also considering bringing in an investor who could take majority control and inject funds to secure the company’s long-term viability.

sourceText: Harvested from the cold, pristine waters off Hokkaido island, the Yesso scallop is no mere mollusc. It is a prize of the culinary world, sought after for its sweet, buttery flesh. Chinese gourmands, in particular, are so partial to Hokkaido’s famous scallops as to have made their country the top destination for the Japanese delicacy.
targetText: The Yesso scallop, harvested from Hokkaido’s cold waters, is prized for its sweet, buttery flesh, with China being the top destination for this sought-after Japanese delicacy.

sourceText: The humble scallop may seem like an unlikely pawn on the chessboard of diplomacy but history has shown that food can be a sensitive topic in international relations. In 2021, the pineapple was at the centre of a diplomatic row, which started with China banning imports of the fruit from Taiwan. The support that Tokyo showed to Taiwan that year — ordering a record 19,000 tons of the rebranded “freedom pineapples”  — was repaid in November 2025 when Taipei took up “sushi diplomacy” as a response to China’s strongarm tactics against Japan. India, too, is not unfamiliar with the pains and pleasures of gastrodiplomacy: Thorny as Bengalis’ favourite ilish maachh (hilsa) is, Bangladesh’s periodic suspension of supply to India has been harder to swallow.
targetText: Scallops may seem trivial, but food often plays a role in diplomacy. Past examples include China banning Taiwanese pineapples in 2021, Tokyo’s support via “freedom pineapples,” Taipei’s 2025 “sushi diplomacy,” and India facing supply suspensions of Bangladesh’s prized hilsa fish.

sourceText: There is a faraway country where every silence is punctuated by the sound of man’s best friend chewing dutifully on man’s child’s homework notebook. Where everyone has an infinite number of dead grandmothers. Where every adult gets food poisoning on Monday morning. This country has its own currency, called the “doctor’s note”. The justice system there faces a serious challenge: Police stations are besieged by legions of rodents in cahoots with criminal gangs, seeking to eat the evidence.
targetText: In a fantastical country, dogs chew on children’s homework, everyone has countless deceased grandmothers, adults get Monday food poisoning, the currency is a “doctor’s note,” and the justice system struggles as rodents allied with criminals eat evidence in police stations.

sourceText: The rats appear to have tunnelled their way to a victory in Jharkhand, where they supposedly ate 200 kg of ganja that was part of the evidence in a drugs case. Acquitting the accused last month, a court referred to a station diary entry noting the gnawing of the ganja. “This casts a suspicion on the very seizure of the case and its handling by the police,” the court said. However, there are precedents. In Mathura in 2022, the rats reportedly destroyed more than 500 kg of confiscated cannabis according to the police.
targetText: In Jharkhand, rats allegedly destroyed 200 kg of cannabis evidence, leading a court to acquit the accused and question the seizure and police handling. Similar incidents occurred in Mathura in 2022, where over 500 kg of confiscated cannabis was reportedly eaten by rats.

sourceText: Over the past decade or so, driven by the widespread adoption of digital platforms, there has been a dramatic surge in the numbers of gig workers across the country. A NITI Aayog report pegged gig and platform workers at 7.7 million in 2020-21, estimated to touch 23.5 million by 2029-30. A few examples illustrate the scale. In the second quarter of 2025-26, Zomato had about 5.5 lakh average monthly delivery partners, Blinkit had about 3.39 lakh, while in 2023, Uber had already crossed 1 million drivers using its platform.
targetText: The rise of digital platforms has fueled rapid growth in India’s gig workforce, from 7.7 million in 2020–21 to an estimated 23.5 million by 2029–30, with companies like Zomato, Blinkit, and Uber employing hundreds of thousands to over a million workers.

sourceText: A little over a decade ago, in Paris, climate delegates inked a pact that was seen as a ray of hope for a world unsettled by ecological upheavals. 2025 began with US President Donald Trump pulling out the country responsible for more than a quarter of all GHG emissions since 1750 from the landmark treaty. In the months that followed, Trump delivered on his campaign promise of increased support to the fossil fuel sector aggressively.
targetText: A decade ago, the Paris climate pact offered hope amid global ecological crises, but in 2025, US President Donald Trump withdrew the US—responsible for over a quarter of historic emissions—and aggressively boosted fossil fuel support.

sourceText: Often, just outside the frame of the video that goes viral, there is a quiet and resolute presence. Take the incident, in the closing days of 2025, in a cafe in Bareilly. Vigilantes attacked a birthday party of a 22-year-old woman, purportedly because two young people in the group belonged to the Muslim community. And yet listen to her, three days later, and amid the bleakness, there is reason to hope. It lies in her refusal to let the goons have the last word: “I cannot understand who gave these assailants the authority to judge people and decide who I should be friends with,” she told this newspaper.
targetText: In Bareilly at the end of 2025, vigilantes attacked a woman’s birthday party over the presence of Muslim friends. Despite the violence, the woman remains defiant, rejecting their authority to dictate her friendships.

sourceText: Perhaps the biggest red herring was a simple word, used by laypeople every day when they strike a bargain. In 2025, every “deal” became a mystery, an announcement followed by a waiting game. The man with the orange tan has announced deals — on peace and trade — but wars continue, and the “strong fundamentals” of bilateral ties continue not to deliver.
targetText: In 2025, the word “deal” became misleading, as promises of peace and trade by the man with the orange tan failed to stop wars or improve bilateral relations, turning announcements into a frustrating waiting game.

sourceText: From Tambalahatti village in Andhra Pradesh emerged T C Deepika, the captain of India’s T20 World Cup-winning Blind Women’s Cricket Team. She grew up in poverty, but Deepika didn’t let anything come in the way of chasing her dreams. The triumph came just weeks after the Harmanpreet Kaur-led team won its first major title by beating South Africa in the summit clash of the ICC Women’s World Cup. After near misses, the win brought silverware the team deserved after years of living in the shadow of male cricketers. The cricketers were not the only ones who made it a year of women’s sports.
targetText: T C Deepika from Tambalahatti, Andhra Pradesh, led India’s Blind Women’s Cricket Team to a T20 World Cup victory, marking a major achievement for women’s sports shortly after Harmanpreet Kaur’s team won the ICC Women’s World Cup, ending years of living in the shadow of male cricketers.

sourceText: Like Deepika, armless archer Sheetal Devi defied the odds to win on the world stage. Already an Asian Championship, Asian Para Games and Paralympics medalist, 18-year-old Sheetal from Kishtwar in J&K became a Para World Champion in Gwangju, South Korea. In chess, Divya Deshmukh won the Women’s Chess World Cup in Batumi in Georgia in July. Divya, 19, and the trailblazer Koneru Humpy, almost double her age, played the final. With the victory in Batumi, Divya also became a grandmaster, only the fourth woman from India to earn the prestigious title.
targetText: Armless archer Sheetal Devi of Kishtwar, J&K, became a Para World Champion, adding to her Asian and Paralympic medals. In chess, 19-year-old Divya Deshmukh defeated veteran Koneru Humpy to win the Women’s Chess World Cup and became India’s fourth female grandmaster.

sourceText: After Khaleda Zia’s death, with Sheikh Hasina in exile, Bangladesh faces an election that will see the “battle of begums” no more. For a nation grappling with unresolved historical legacies and current crises, with the interim government led by Muhammad Yunus failing to step up to its mandate, the death of Bangladesh’s first woman prime minister and BNP chief marks the end of an era. Her passing coincides with the return of her son, Tarique Rahman, from 17 years of self-imposed exile in London.
targetText: With Khaleda Zia’s death and Sheikh Hasina in exile, Bangladesh faces an election without the “battle of begums.” Her passing, amid unresolved national challenges and a faltering interim government, marks the end of an era as her son, Tarique Rahman, returns from 17 years in self-imposed exile.

sourceText: For decades, citizens from the Northeast have, all too often, been made to feel exoticised and othered. Racialised abuse has followed them into classrooms, rented apartments, marketplaces and thoroughfares, even erupting in violence. Chakma’s death joins a grim ledger of such fatalities, including the murder of 20-year-old Nido Taniam from Arunachal Pradesh in the Capital in 2014. Earlier, in 2012, following ethnic clashes in Assam, there was an exodus of people from the Northeast from cities such as Bengaluru, Hyderabad, Chennai and Pune, spurred by the mass circulation of inflammatory messages.
targetText: People from Northeast India have long faced racial abuse and discrimination, sometimes leading to violence. Chakma’s death adds to a history of such incidents, including Nido Taniam’s murder in 2014, and past ethnic tensions like the 2012 Assam clashes that caused Northeasterners to flee major cities.

sourceText: For several weeks now, Ukraine has been confronted with a stark choice: Surrender territory in the east and accede to Russian President Vladimir Putin’s demands, or continue fighting a war of attrition with mounting costs. That the war persists despite consistent pressure from Trump on Zelenskyy to opt for the former — articulated in Washington’s original 28-point plan —underscores Kyiv’s determination not to cede land. Trump and Zelenskyy both acknowledged on Sunday that the future of the Donbas remained unresolved.
targetText: Ukraine faces a difficult choice: surrender eastern territory to Russia or continue a costly war. Despite Trump pressuring Zelenskyy to concede under a 28-point plan, Kyiv remains determined, and the future of Donbas is still unresolved.

sourceText: While Soviet psychologist Lev Vygotsky emphasised the relevance of language in cognitive development, Swiss scholar Jean Piaget framed it differently. Far away from this debate, culturally and geographically, the best political minds of India, in Constitution Hall, were discussing the trajectory of a new democracy in which everyday politics and culture is shaped by language hierarchy. One of the few Adivasi members of the Constituent Assembly, Jaipal Singh Munda, stood up and spoke in Mundari, and demanded recognition for tribal languages and identities.
targetText: While Vygotsky highlighted language in cognitive development and Piaget viewed it differently, India’s Constituent Assembly debated language’s role in democracy. Adivasi member Jaipal Singh Munda spoke in Mundari, urging recognition for tribal languages and identities.

sourceText: The Constitution in Santhali offers the Santhali people easier access to a document that enshrines the rights for which leaders like Munda fought. With a population of over 7 million, the Santhals are the third-largest tribe in the country. Yet, it was only in 2003 that the Santhali language was included in Schedule VIII. Notably, it was on Murmu’s insistence — as a minister in Odisha, she requested the then Prime Minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, to give official status to Santhali — that the language got its long-due recognition.
targetText: The Constitution in Santhali gives the 7-million-strong Santhal community easier access to their rights. The language, India’s third-largest tribal tongue, was officially recognized in 2003 after Murmu, then an Odisha minister, urged Prime Minister Vajpayee to include it in Schedule VIII.

sourceText: For the “most powerful man in the world,” perhaps it’s time to do less. Between tariffs and trade deals, the hot-and-cold vibes with his counterparts in Russia and China, and threats of invading South America — all the while ensuring the family business benefits — every action by Donald Trump has an outsized reaction. So, maybe, just for a few months, let the news cycle hum along without hinting at ending the global order.
targetText: For the world’s most powerful man, Donald Trump, constant actions—from trade wars to global threats—create outsized reactions. Perhaps he should step back for a few months and let the news cycle proceed without jeopardizing the global order.

sourceText: The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) closed out the year with the successful launch of the LVM3-M6 mission in which it deployed a 6,100-kg commercial satellite, Bluebird Block-2, into low-earth orbit. It was the heaviest payload carried by an Indian rocket. Commercial satellite launches, even from other countries, have become routine for the ISRO, having put as many as 434 foreign satellites into space till now belonging to 34 different countries.
targetText: ISRO ended the year by successfully launching its heaviest payload yet—a 6,100-kg commercial satellite, Bluebird Block-2, into low-Earth orbit. The agency has also routinely launched 434 foreign satellites from 34 countries.

sourceText: At the start of the year, the ISRO demonstrated its ability to dock and undock two satellites in space in the SpaDeX mission, an ability that is vital to its ambitions to set up a space station of its own and send more sophisticated lunar and other missions. That was followed by the long-awaited NISAR mission in July, the first of its kind, a joint India-US space mission, in which the satellite was a novelty. It was a unique satellite that carried two Synthetic Aperture Radars of different frequencies designed to work together to produce the most detailed images of Earth ever captured from space.
targetText: At the start of the year, ISRO showcased satellite docking and undocking in the SpaDeX mission, a key step toward a space station and advanced missions. In July, it launched the joint India-US NISAR mission, featuring a unique satellite with two complementary Synthetic Aperture Radars for the most detailed Earth images ever.

sourceText: In the introduction to Vinod Kumar Shukla’s Treasurer of Piggy Banks, poet and translator Arvind Krishna Mehrotra sums up the oeuvre of the poet and writer from Chhattisgarh: “A line of Shukla is like a line of Shukla. It ‘mirrors nothing’ but itself. Reading him can be disorienting, even vertiginous, like seeing Op art.” Shukla, who died on December 23 at the age of 88, occupied a singular place in Hindi — and Indian — literature, a writer whose work stood slightly apart from its moment, quietly undoing expectations about narrative and form, about what and whom great literature must speak for.
targetText: Vinod Kumar Shukla, who passed away at 88, held a unique place in Hindi and Indian literature. His work, described as self-contained and disorienting, quietly challenged conventional expectations of narrative, form, and the purpose of great literature.

sourceText: There is an anecdote about Shukla that appears in the introduction to a collection of his short stories translated into English, Blue is like Blue (2019). At the Jaipur Literature Festival one year, he was bemused to see a serpentine queue of readers waiting for J M Coetzee to sign their books. Shukla did not know who Coetzee was, but more importantly, he could not understand spectacle around writing.
targetText: An anecdote in Blue is like Blue recalls Shukla at the Jaipur Literature Festival, puzzled by a long queue of readers for J.M. Coetzee’s book signing. Unfamiliar with Coetzee and indifferent to literary spectacle, Shukla was bemused by the attention.

sourceText: Cheese has been unfairly maligned. A growing body of research shows that it is sugar and not fat that is the main culprit for many lifestyle diseases, from obesity and hypertension to diabetes.
targetText: Cheese has been wrongly blamed, as research indicates sugar—not fat—is the main cause of lifestyle diseases like obesity, hypertension, and diabetes.

sourceText: The threats to the Aravallis are well documented. On more than one occasion in the past 30 years, the Supreme Court has ruled against violations of environmental norms in the mountain range. Last year, the Court found that the inconsistency in criteria used to define the hills was one of the major reasons for illegal quarrying in the Aravallis.
targetText: The Aravallis face well-documented threats, with the Supreme Court repeatedly ruling against environmental violations over the past 30 years. Last year, it noted that inconsistent criteria for defining the hills contributed significantly to illegal quarrying.

sourceText: The last few years have witnessed a welcome embrace of free trade agreements by the Indian government. Within this year, three trade deals have been wrapped up — one with the UK, another with Oman a few days ago, and now negotiations have concluded with New Zealand. The India-EFTA trade agreement (it includes the countries of Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland), which was signed in March last year, also took effect on October 1. These agreements, which come after similar deals were signed earlier with the UAE and Australia, signal the desire to seek greater integration with global markets.
targetText: India has increasingly embraced free trade agreements, finalising deals this year with the UK, Oman, and New Zealand, and bringing the India-EFTA pact into force. Along with earlier agreements with the UAE and Australia, these moves reflect India’s push for deeper integration with global markets.

sourceText: If Sreenivasan had only ever written Sandesam (1991), a satire about ideological hypocrisy in Kerala politics, or played one half of the jobless duo in Nadodikkattu (1987), which drew on the unemployment crisis driving out the state’s youth, or made Vadakkunokkiyanthram (1989), a sharp send-up of the Malayali man’s insecurities, he would have earned a place among the icons of Malayalam cinema. But the actor-writer-director, 69, who died last week, combined his rapier wit with remarkable productivity, writing and acting in over 200 films.
targetText: Even if Sreenivasan were known only for classics like Sandesam, Nadodikkattu, or Vadakkunokkiyanthram, he would be a legend of Malayalam cinema. But the actor-writer-director, who died last week at 69, went far beyond these films, pairing sharp social satire with extraordinary productivity by writing and acting in over 200 movies.

sourceText: A gifted actor, Sreenivasan was widely admired for his understated style and pitch-perfect delivery in both comic and dramatic scenes. Arguably, though, his most lasting impact comes from his work as a writer. Sreenivasan had a rare ability to express bitter truths in the most palatable way.
targetText: Sreenivasan was a gifted actor known for his subtle performances, but his greatest legacy lies in his writing, where he uniquely conveyed harsh social truths with wit and accessibility.

sourceText: For the so-called liberal-progressive elites, the “Epstein class” poses an especially uncomfortable question. The recurring appearance of figures such as former US president Bill Clinton, intellectual Noam Chomsky, Microsoft founder Bill Gates and former Harvard president and treasury secretary Larry Summers in the documents poses a challenge to claims of moral seriousness and weakens the reflex to treat these disclosures primarily as ammunition against political opponents.
targetText: The repeated appearance of prominent liberal figures in the Epstein-related documents challenges liberal-progressive elites’ moral claims and undermines the tendency to view the disclosures only as tools to attack political opponents.

sourceText: With 260 positive cases in 2024, India is the only nation to hit triple digits, surpassing countries with far more rigorous testing regimes like China, Germany and France. This is not just a statistical anomaly; it is a systemic failure that threatens to impact India’s ambitious bid for the 2036 Olympics.
targetText: India recorded 260 positive cases in 2024, making it the only country to reach triple digits, ahead of nations with stricter testing like China, Germany and France. This reflects a systemic failure that could undermine India’s bid to host the 2036 Olympics.

sourceText: The Allahabad High Court’s order directing police to offer protection to 12 women in live-in relationships reaffirms the constitutional commitment to personal liberty at a moment when such freedoms appear increasingly contested. “The concept of a live-in relationship may not be acceptable to all, but it cannot be said that such a relationship is an illegal one or that living together without the sanctity of the marriage constitutes an offence,” held the court, rejecting the state’s claim that cohabitation outside marriage corrodes the “social fabric”.
targetText: The Allahabad High Court ordered police protection for 12 women in live-in relationships, reaffirming the constitutional right to personal liberty. The court held that while such relationships may not be socially acceptable to everyone, they are not illegal, and living together without marriage does not constitute an offence, rejecting the state’s claim that they harm the social fabric.

sourceText: Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s three-nation tour to Jordan, Ethiopia and Oman this week underlined India’s bid to consolidate its strategic footprint in the Middle East and the Horn of Africa at a moment of unprecedented geopolitical change in the region. US President Donald Trump’s success in negotiating a ceasefire of sorts in Gaza, his attack on Iranian nuclear facilities, a more intensive commercial outreach to the oil-rich Gulf states, and effort to widen the ambit of the Abraham Accords underline the shifting geopolitical terrain.
targetText: Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s visit to Jordan, Ethiopia and Oman highlighted India’s effort to strengthen its strategic presence in the Middle East and the Horn of Africa amid major geopolitical shifts, including US-led moves on Gaza, Iran, Gulf outreach and the expansion of the Abraham Accords.

sourceText: The visit saw substantive bilateral outcomes, elevating of partnerships and signing of key agreements. In Amman, PM Modi and King Abdullah II reviewed ties on the 75th diplomatic anniversary. Besides the focus on expanded trade, the discussions focused on regional developments, including in Gaza, and counter-terrorism. In Addis Ababa, PM Modi upgraded ties with Ethiopia to a “Strategic Partnership” with a roadmap for rapid expansion of trade, investment and defence cooperation.
targetText: The visit produced concrete bilateral results, including upgraded partnerships and key agreements. In Jordan, PM Modi and King Abdullah II reviewed relations on the 75th anniversary of diplomatic ties, with discussions on trade, regional issues such as Gaza, and counter-terrorism. In Ethiopia, India elevated ties to a Strategic Partnership, setting out plans to expand trade, investment and defence cooperation.

sourceText: On Wednesday, the Indian rupee registered its best gain against the US dollar in seven months following an intervention by the Reserve Bank of India. As a result of the RBI selling dollars, the rupee’s exchange rate versus the dollar rose by over 1 per cent during the day. By the close of day, the rupee had gained 0.7 per cent over the dollar and the exchange rate had shifted from 91.05 to a dollar to 90.09 to a dollar.
targetText: The Indian rupee posted its strongest gain in seven months after the Reserve Bank of India intervened by selling dollars. This pushed the rupee up by over 1% during the day, ending with a 0.7% gain as the exchange rate improved from ₹91.05 to ₹90.09 per US dollar.

sourceText: At one level, the RBI’s intervention is nothing new, and is understandable. In the most recent monetary policy review on December 5, RBI Governor Sanjay Malhotra sounded sanguine about the rupee’s exchange rate trajectory as he delineated the RBI’s approach. “Our stated policy, always, has been that we allow the markets to determine (the value of rupee). We don’t target any price levels or any (price) bands... Our effort always has been to reduce any abnormal or excessive volatility and that is what we will continue to endeavour,” he said.
targetText: The RBI’s intervention in the rupee market is routine and justified. In the December 5 monetary policy review, Governor Sanjay Malhotra said the RBI lets market forces decide the rupee’s value and does not target specific exchange rate levels. Its role is limited to controlling abnormal or excessive volatility, a policy it will continue to follow.

sourceText: Such is the craze for the young that 20-year-old leg-spinner Izaz Sawariya, who has not even played domestic cricket but uploaded his bowling videos to Instagram, made his way to the auction. He didn’t get picked as there weren’t slots in the mini auction. But it won’t be a surprise to see him play domestic T20 leagues soon. His presence in the auction also says a lot about talent scouting for the IPL.
targetText: The strong focus on young talent is evident as 20-year-old leg-spinner Izaz Sawariya, who has not yet played domestic cricket but shared his bowling videos on Instagram, made it to the IPL auction. Although he was not picked due to limited slots in the mini auction, he is likely to feature in domestic T20 leagues soon. His inclusion highlights the evolving and expansive talent scouting methods used for the IPL.

sourceText: In recent years, the government has promoted nuclear power as a key component in the country’s efforts to achieve energy security. It’s a relatively clean source of electricity that doesn’t have the uncertainties associated with renewables, and can, therefore, fulfil the need for baseload power. However, nuclear energy accounts for only 3 per cent of the overall power generation today. The country has set a short-term goal to increase its nuclear power capacity to 22.5 GW by 2032, and a long-term target to reach 100 GW by 2047.
targetText: The government sees nuclear power as important for energy security because it is a clean and reliable source of baseload electricity. Despite this, nuclear energy currently contributes only 3% of total power generation. The country aims to expand nuclear capacity to 22.5 GW by 2032 and 100 GW by 2047.

sourceText: Foreign investors, including sovereign funds from West Asia, have reportedly expressed early interest in part-financing the country's objectives to scale up nuclear power, including entering the manufacturing value chain of small modular reactors (SMRs). These reactors address the limitations of traditional nuclear plants — they are less expensive, have shorter construction times, require less fuel and have enhanced safety features, including the ability to shut down in emergencies without human intervention.
targetText: Foreign investors, including West Asian sovereign funds, have shown early interest in financing the expansion of nuclear power and participating in the manufacturing of small modular reactors (SMRs). SMRs overcome many drawbacks of conventional nuclear plants as they are cheaper, faster to build, use less fuel, and have advanced safety systems that can shut down automatically during emergencies.

sourceText: That the attackers targeted a Jewish gathering celebrating the first day of Hanukkah suggests that they were motivated by anti-semitism. Initial reports also indicate that they were “inspired” by ISIS. In the internet age, tackling such radicalisation is one of the most pressing challenges for nation-states. The first line of defence against such attacks is a robust intelligence-gathering framework, and the establishment of protocols for containing the threats.
targetText: The attack on a Jewish gathering celebrating Hanukkah points to an anti-Semitic motive, with early reports suggesting the attackers were inspired by ISIS. In the digital age, preventing such radicalisation is a major challenge for governments. Strong intelligence gathering and clear protocols to identify and contain threats are the first line of defence against such attacks.

sourceText: Australia’s intelligence agency reportedly examined one of the attackers six years ago over his ties to a terrorism cell connected to the Islamic State. If there were holes in the country’s intelligence framework or if actionable information was ignored, these issues must be addressed. At the same time, it is important to guard against excessive or extreme action. The provocative words of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu about Australia’s Labor government and Prime Minister Anthony Albanese are an example of how not to politicise the act of terrorism.
targetText: Australia’s intelligence agency had investigated one of the attackers years earlier for links to an Islamic State–connected terror cell. If intelligence failures or ignored warnings existed, they need to be corrected, while avoiding excessive or extreme responses. The remarks by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu targeting Australia’s Labor government and Prime Minister Anthony Albanese show the dangers of politicising acts of terrorism.

sourceText: Delhi’s latest descent into “severe” air pollution — the Air Quality Index (AQI) has been well over the range of 400 — has arrived without many of its usual culprits: Smoke from stubble burning or unusual winter chill. Instead, the city has been caught out by a near-total drop in wind speed and a shallow atmospheric layer trapping pollutants closer to the ground, leaving the city’s own emissions — from vehicles, construction and industry — to accumulate unchecked. Between 2015 and November 2025, the average annual AQI in Delhi has been 235, much higher than the WHO-mandated safety levels. The Lancet Countdown 2025 Report pegged the number of pollution deaths at 1.72 million in 2022.
targetText: Delhi is experiencing “severe” air pollution, with AQI levels above 400, despite the absence of typical causes like stubble burning or extreme winter cold. The main factors are stagnant winds and a shallow atmospheric layer that trap the city’s own emissions from vehicles, construction, and industry. Between 2015 and 2025, Delhi’s average annual AQI was 235, far above WHO safety limits, and pollution caused an estimated 1.72 million deaths in 2022, according to the Lancet Countdown 2025 Report.

sourceText: For some time now, the Election Commission of India has seemed to be less than what it used to be. The institution that, ever since it was re-energised in the 1990s, has ranked among India’s most trusted, overseeing and ensuring free and fair elections in the world’s most diverse democracy, has invited questions about its impartiality.
targetText: The Election Commission of India, once highly trusted for ensuring free and fair elections since its revitalization in the 1990s, has recently faced doubts about its impartiality.

sourceText: Its successive electoral defeats have evidently unsettled the Congress, but by raising the decibel levels, it draws attention to its own flailing. Targeting the EC and the EVM, or calling for a return to the ballot paper, is a poor stand-in for the political work the party refuses to do, be it in terms of reconnecting to the people, or looking within. Of course, if the party has verifiable proof about flaws in the poll process, it must make its case. As the Karnataka investigation shows, there have been glaring irregularities in Aland.
targetText: Repeated electoral losses have unsettled the Congress, but blaming the Election Commission or EVMs distracts from its own shortcomings. Instead of focusing on internal reforms or reconnecting with voters, the party raises noise. However, if it has verifiable evidence of poll flaws, it should present it, as seen in the Karnataka Aland case where clear irregularities were reported.

sourceText: Some members of the Assembly have objections and disagreements about the proposal to rename their position as MWP (Member of Welsh Parliament). Some believe the new title is clean and effective, but others fear it could cause confusion. Discussions and debates are ongoing within the Assembly on this issue. Currently, it is not easy to reach an agreement on this proposal.
targetText: Assembly members are divided over renaming their position to MWP. Debates continue with no agreement reached yet.

sourceText: The main reason is that there is a plan to rename the Assembly as the 'Welsh Parliament'. This change may alter the institutions identity and role. Along with the renaming, members positions and responsibilities may also be affected. Therefore, many members are cautious and concerned about this proposal.
targetText: Plans to rename the Assembly as 'Welsh Parliament' may affect its identity and members' roles. Many members are cautious about the proposal.

sourceText: All AMs involved in politics are worried that this decision could affect their public image. They fear that people may not take the issue seriously and might mock them. Such reactions could negatively affect their credibility and political influence. That is why they appear very cautious and sensitive about the whole matter.
targetText: AMs worry the decision may harm their public image and credibility. They are proceeding with caution due to potential ridicule.

sourceText: A Labour AM said that their group was concerned that this proposal should not be associated with names like TWP and PWP. They believed that such short and unclear titles could cause confusion among the public. The group feared that such names would reduce the seriousness of the political issue. Therefore, they favored caution and clarity on this matter.
targetText: The Labour AM group opposed confusing titles like TWP and PWP. They emphasized clarity to maintain the seriousness of the issue.

sourceText: For readers outside Wales, it is important to understand that some words have different meanings in the Welsh language. In Welsh, the word 'twp' means foolish or stupid. Similarly, the word 'pwp' is considered to mean dirt or excrement. This is why there has been sensitivity and concern regarding abbreviations similar to these words.
targetText: Certain Welsh words like 'twp' and 'pwp' have negative meanings. This has caused concern over using similar abbreviations.

sourceText: A Plaid AM said that the entire group was not happy and they suggested other options. They believed that the current proposal could affect the groups opinion and public perception. They said that a better and more suitable option should be found before making a final decision. The group was not fully satisfied and felt it was necessary to consider all aspects.
targetText: The Plaid AM group was unhappy with the current proposal and suggested alternatives. They want a better option before finalizing any decision.

sourceText: A Welsh political party said that their group was 'independent-minded' regarding the name change, but they also noted that with a small verbal change, MWP could sound like 'muppet'. This raised concerns that the public or media might treat it as a joke. The party said that considering this potential negative impact, the decision on the name change should be made thoughtfully.
targetText: The party raised concerns that MWP could sound like 'muppet' and cause ridicule. They recommend careful consideration before finalizing the name.

sourceText: In this context, the pronunciation of the letter 'w' in Welsh is similar to the pronunciation of the letter 'u' in Yorkshire English. That means the sound of 'w' in Welsh can somewhat resemble 'oo' or 'u'. For this reason, some words pronunciation may confuse outsiders. Understanding such linguistic differences is necessary to correctly interpret the meaning and sound of words.
targetText: Welsh 'w' sounds like 'u' in Yorkshire English, which may confuse outsiders. Understanding these differences is key to interpreting words correctly.

sourceText: The Assembly Commission, currently drafting the legal proposal on the name change, said: 'The final decision about what members are called will certainly be a matter for the members themselves.' The Commission also clarified that the final decision will fully depend on the individual rights and preferences of the members. Therefore, members opinions and consent will be given importance when deciding on name changes or titles.
targetText: The Assembly Commission stated that members themselves will decide their titles. Individual opinions and consent will guide the final decision.

sourceText: According to the Wales Government Act 2017, the Welsh Assembly has the authority to change its name. Under this law, the Assembly can independently decide to change its institutional name. The Act ensures that such a decision is taken fully under legislative procedures and rules. While exercising this right, it is necessary to respect members’ opinions and the constitutional framework.
targetText: The Wales Government Act 2017 allows the Assembly to change its name legally. Members' opinions and constitutional rules must be respected in the process.

sourceText: In June, the Commission reported the results of public consultation on the proposals to rename the Assembly as the 'Welsh Parliament', which received strong support.
